channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rishi Sunak’s Challenge: Unifying the Party and Fixing the Economy
item.description: The Conservative Party is fractured and Britain’s public finances are battered. That will test the political skills of a leader who has been involved in national politics for only seven years.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain speaks outside 10 Downing Street after taking office on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Warns Russia Against Nuclear Attack Amid Mounting Alarm
item.description: President Biden told Russia it would be a “serious mistake” to use tactical nuclear weapons. His comments reflect growing worry among allies that Moscow may be searching for a pretext for a radiological attack.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman cycled past a destroyed house on Tuesday after receiving humanitarian aid in the village of Khreshchenivka, which was liberated from Russian forces in early October.

item.title: What Are ‘Dirty Bombs’ and Why Is Russia Talking About Them?
item.description: The idea of radiological dispersal devices is not new, and Russia’s claim that Ukraine would build and use one has been met with scorn from the West.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian military training in Kyiv in October. Russia has accused Ukraine of preparing to use a dirty bomb.

item.title: Airstrike Kills at Least 80 During Outdoor Concert in Myanmar
item.description: The bombing was the deadliest aerial attack mounted by the military regime since it seized power in a coup last year.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Destroyed wooden structures near Aung Bar Lay Village, Kachin State, in Myanmar, on Monday. Airstrikes by Myanmar’s military have killed scores of people since the coup last year.

item.title: Germany’s Allies Challenge Its Stances on Ukraine and Energy
item.description: The government has dismissed criticism of its refusal to provide modern tanks to Ukraine and its massive energy subsidy for its own citizens. But its friends are bridling.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, right; Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal of Ukraine, center; and Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, at a conference in Berlin on Tuesday on the reconstruction of Ukraine. Germany has pushed back against the idea that it is isolating itself.

item.title: Who Are Rishi Sunak’s Top Cabinet Ministers?
item.description: The new prime minister named people with high-level experience, several of them to posts they have held before, sending a message of stability after a period of upheaval.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain appointed cabinet members on Tuesday, mostly drawing on lawmakers who have held prominent positions in the past.

item.title: Some Britons fear Sunak is too rich to understand working-class suffering.
item.description: A British worker earning the median wage would have to have been working since the Stone Age to amass the new prime minister’s fortune, one group estimated.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, left, and his wife, Akshata Murty, were estimated to be worth more than $800 million, according to The Times of London.

item.title: Deadly Israeli Raid in Nablus Targets New Palestinian Militia
item.description: At least six Palestinians were killed in a night of violence in the West Bank, raising tensions further ahead of elections in Israel next week.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Mourners carrying the bodies of Palestinians who were among those killed in an overnight Israeli raid in the occupied West Bank city of Nablus on Tuesday.

item.title: A Social Media Status Update
item.description: Top social media apps are struggling after a decade of dominance.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:description: Social media companies are having a troubling year.

item.title: A 23-Million-Year-Old Fossil Is Carried Away by Parties Unknown
item.description: The whale fossil, a cherished local attraction, was taken from a riverbank in broad daylight by two men with a rock saw and chisel, residents say.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The town of Westport, on New Zealand’s remote West Coast, about 60 miles from where the fossil was taken.

item.title: Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera and More: Visiting Mexico City’s House Museums
item.description: Curiosity about the daily lives of the famous draws us to the places they lived. In Coyoacán it’s possible to commune with the ghosts of Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera, Leon Trotsky and more.
item.dc:creator: Francine Prose
item.media:credit: Adrian Wilson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leon Trotsky, in exile from the Soviet Union, lived at this house in Mexico City’s Coyoacán neighborhood. It is now a museum.

item.title: How Elon Musk Became a Geopolitical Chaos Agent
item.description: The world’s richest man has inserted himself in some of the world’s most combustible conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz, Adam Satariano and Chang Che
item.media:description: Elon Musk, center, met the Chinese Premier Li Keqiang in Beijing in 2019. Mr. Musk has been criticized for statements regarding China’s interest in Taiwan.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Istanbul
item.description: Istanbul is unfathomable: old and new, real and surreal, melancholic and absurd. Elif Shafak, one of its foremost novelists, reveals its secrets.
item.dc:creator: Elif Shafak
item.category: Istanbul: A Tale of Three Cities (Book)

item.title: Shunned by the West, Russia and Myanmar Form a Partnership of Unequals
item.description: Myanmar gets resources and ammunition, while Russia gets a customer at a time when it is struggling for revenues. Both can use the other to undermine Western sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Myanmar fans and soldiers at the annual International Army Games in Russia in August. Myanmar’s engagement with Russia has grown this year.

item.title: Climate Pledges Are Falling Short, and a Chaotic Future Looks More Like Reality
item.description: With an annual summit next month, the United Nations assessed progress on countries’ past emissions commitments. Severe disruption would be hard to avoid on the current trajectory.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: A displaced Somali woman and her children near the carcasses of their livestock, killed by drought, in the country’s Gedo Region in May.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Tensions are flaring between Germany and its allies.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany said criticism of its policy on military aid to Ukraine was unfounded.

item.title: Biden Says Russian Use of a Nuclear Weapon Would Be a ‘Serious Mistake’
item.description: President Biden’s remarks reflect the urgent concern in Washington and among Western allies that Russia may be searching for a pretext to unleash a battlefield nuclear weapon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian officials have accused Russia of secretly building dirty bombs at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Prison Term Is Upheld by Russian Court
item.description: The W.N.B.A. athlete is facing nine years in a Russian prison on a drug charge. A prisoner swap may be her only path home.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko, Neil MacFarquhar and Jonathan Abrams
item.media:description: Brittney Griner speaking with her lawyers in a courtroom in July. Addressing the court on Tuesday, she protested her unusually long sentence.

item.title: A Secret, Failed Oil Deal: How the U.S.-Saudi Relationship Ruptured
item.description: After Saudi leaders pushed to slash oil production despite a visit by President Biden, American officials have been left fuming that they were duped.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti, Edward Wong and Adam Entous
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: President Biden arriving in Saudi Arabia in July. The administration thought it had secured a promise from the Saudis to keep oil flowing in a bid to stabilize prices.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Tensions Rise in the West Bank
item.description: Plus Myanmar’s junta kills dozens and Brittney Griner faces nine years in a Russian penal colony.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Mourners attended the funeral of Palestinians killed in an overnight Israeli raid, in the occupied West Bank city of Nablus on Tuesday.

item.title: Amid Backlash, Liberal House Democrats Retract Call to Pursue Ukraine Ceasefire
item.description: One day after issuing a letter urging President Biden to seek direct diplomatic talks with Russia, progressives withdrew that appeal. The move reflected deepening divisions over the conflict.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Pramila Jayapal of Washington, the letter’s principal author, faulted unnamed aides for releasing the letter.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Is a Brexit Supporter. Here’s What He’ll Have to Navigate.
item.description: While he was among the first to come out in favor of Britain’s exit from the European Union, he hasn’t shared the Conservative Party’s hard-line approach.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak in 2019. His early support for Brexit helped fuel his political rise.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Is the Youngest UK Prime Minister of Modern Times
item.description: Mr. Sunak is 42 and started out in Parliament in 2015.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak was appointed as chancellor of the Exchequer in 2020 under former Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Keeps Jeremy Hunt as UK Chancellor
item.description: Mr. Hunt became Britain’s top finance official after his predecessor’s plan for tax cuts and borrowing caused financial turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Mark Landler
item.media:description: Jeremy Hunt was appointed as chancellor of the Exchequer by Liz Truss, Rishi Sunak’s predecessor, days before she resigned.

item.title: Emperor Penguins Are Protected Under the Endangered Species Act
item.description: Under the new listing, federal agencies are required to reduce threats to emperor penguins, which are vulnerable to warming temperatures and melting sea ice caused by climate change.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Kyodo News Stills, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Emperor penguins in Antarctica in 2017. The animals are threatened by the disappearance of their sea ice habitat.

item.title: Rishi Sunak’s First Speech as UK Prime Minister: Full Transcript
item.description: In his first address as Britain’s prime minister, Mr. Sunak promised “integrity, professionalism and accountability.”
item.media:description: Britain’s new prime minister, Rishi Sunak, outside 10 Downing Street on Tuesday.

item.title: Trumpism Beyond Trump
item.description: Which version of the Republican Party will win out?
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times

item.title: Old U.K. Ritual Now Has 2 New Participants: King Charles and Rishi Sunak
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II welcomed 15 British prime ministers during her seven-decade reign. Rishi Sunak will be the first to start his time as leader under King Charles III.
item.dc:creator: Peter Robins
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III

item.title: Three Inquiries, but No Answers to Who Blew Holes in Nord Stream Pipelines
item.description: Denmark, Germany and Sweden are all investigating the ruptured pipeline sites, but they remain tight-lipped over who might have caused the damage and why.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Danish Defence, via Agence France-Presse/Getty Images
item.media:description: The gas leak at the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline shortly after the explosions on Sept. 26.

item.title: Why People Are Flocking to a Symbol of Taiwan’s Authoritarian Past
item.description: At a museum dedicated to Taiwan’s not-so-distant authoritarian past, Taiwanese see China’s present, and a dark vision of one possible future under autocratic rule.
item.dc:creator: Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Chris Horton
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jing-Mei White Terror Memorial Park in Taiwan has seen a surge of visitors since Speaker Nancy Pelosi toured the site in August.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Britain’s next leader.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: 3 Palestinians Killed in Shootout With Israeli Forces, Palestinians Say
item.description: Three Palestinians were killed during a firefight with Israeli security forces who had entered Nablus, a flash point city in the occupied West Bank, Palestinian officials said.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: Men carrying the body of Hamdi Sharaf in Nablus, in the occupied West Bank early on Tuesday. Palestinian officials said he was one of three people killed in a clash with Israeli security forces.

item.title: Dietrich Mateschitz, Creator of the Red Bull Empire, Dies at 78
item.description: The Austrian salesman turned a Thai energy drink into a marketing juggernaut that owned sports teams, media outlets and a winning Formula 1 crew.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Dietrich Mateschitz was a salesman for a company that made personal hygiene products when he discovered the elixirs sold in Asian pharmacies as pick-me-ups for workers and truckers.

item.title: Sunak’s Ascent Is a Breakthrough for Diversity, With Privilege
item.description: Rishi Sunak’s ascent to the prime minister’s office is a significant milestone for Britain’s Indian diaspora. But for many, his immense personal wealth has made him less relatable.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating Diwali in northwest London on Monday. As many as 1.5 million people of Indian descent live in England and Wales, making them the largest ethnic group after white Britons.

item.title: Russian Officials Flee Kherson as Russian Troops Dig In for a Battle
item.description: In Kherson, the first Ukrainian city to fall after the Russian invasion, occupation forces appear to be preparing to fight advancing Ukrainian troops.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a heavily shelled schoolyard in the Kherson region, Ukrainian troops searched for explosives and booby traps on Monday.

item.title: House Progressives Urge Biden to Engage in Direct Talks With Russia
item.description: Thirty Democrats called on the Biden administration to “seek a realistic framework for a cease-fire” that is acceptable to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden in Rehoboth Beach, Del., on Friday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Wins Contest to be UK’s Next PM and Confront Economic Storm
item.description: After a period of chaos, Mr. Sunak, a Conservative, faces serious political and economic headwinds. He will be the first person of color and first Hindu to be prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, center, outside Conservative Party headquarters in London on Monday.

item.title: How Rich Is Rishi Sunak, Britain’s New Prime Minister?
item.description: Just how rich is the new prime minister of Britain?
item.dc:creator: Yonette Joseph
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak and his wife, Akshata Murty, at a reception in February for the British Asian Trust in London.

item.title: Venezuelan Migrants Stranded After US Border Policy Change
item.description: They have sold their belongings and trekked across a deadly jungle. Now, tens of thousands Venezuelan migrants are stranded south of the United States, with nowhere to go.
item.dc:creator: David Shortell and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venezuelan migrants on a hill near the border with United States in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico. The United States has started turning back many Venezuelans reaching the border.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Rishi Sunak to Lead Britain
item.description: Plus Chinese markets react to a stronger Xi Jinping and young Chinese pursue quiet dissent.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: South African Leader Unveils Anticorruption Plans, but Doubts Follow
item.description: President Cyril Ramaphosa presented measures that would place even himself and his cabinet under scrutiny. But some analysts question whether the plan will be carried out.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa came to power after the scandal-plagued Zuma years and was seen as someone who could right the ship, an analyst said.

item.title: What Will Rishi Sunak Do as UK’s Prime Minister?
item.description: He has said very little about how he will turn around Britain’s economy or deal with any of the other issues facing the U.K.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak in Cardiff, Wales, in August. Mr. Sunak has said very little in the last week about how he will lead Britain.

item.title: Brittney Griner Doesn’t Expect ‘Miracles to Happen’ With Her Appeal
item.description: If the appeals court near Moscow won’t overrule Ms. Griner’s verdict, it will come into force and she will be sent to a penal colony.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko

item.title: Where Russians Retreated, Ukrainians Find Devastation
item.description: Returning to liberated towns, Ukrainians find destruction on a staggering scale, vital services cut, and the prospect of a lethal winter ahead.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

item.title: Ethiopian Government and Tigray Rebels Are Set to Begin Peace Talks
item.description: Delegations from both sides have traveled to South Africa for the first formal negotiations since the civil war erupted nearly two years ago.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A demonstration in Addis Ababa in support of the Ethiopia armed forces this past weekend.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Will Face Difficult Economic Tests Immediately
item.description: As prime minister, Mr. Sunak will face a vastly different economic backdrop to the one he experienced as finance minister.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: Canary Wharf, a finaincial center in London. The government is under pressure to show how it will keep borrowing in check, in an effort to restore Britain’s fiscal credibility in markets.

item.title: What Will Happen Next to Become UK Prime Minister?
item.description: Liz Truss and Rishi Sunak must now visit Buckingham Palace to meet with King Charles III, who will invite Mr. Sunak to form the next government.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II, in one of her last official duties, met with Liz Truss last month after the lawmaker was named the Tories’ leader.

item.title: Rishi Sunak Makes History as UK’s First Prime Minister of Color
item.description: Born in southern England to parents of Indian heritage, he has spoken of a childhood split between the Hindu temple and cheering on the local soccer team.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle, Shashank Bengali and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Rishi Sunak, a former chancellor of the Exchequer, in August.

item.title: Italy’s New Right-Wing Government Promises to Keep Backing Ukraine
item.description: Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani expressed support for Ukraine, trying to dispel concerns that Italy could undercut Europe’s opposition to the Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Italy’s new prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, center, with her coalition partners Silvio Berlusconi, left, and Matteo Salvini, right.

item.title: A Republican Advantage
item.description: As headlines shift in the weeks before the midterms, so do voters’ top concerns.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
